Yes, here are a few additional resources and tips on workplace accommodations:

1. Job Accommodation Network (JAN): JAN is a free service that provides information on workplace accommodations. Their website includes a searchable database of accommodation options, as well as detailed information on disability-related laws and regulations.

2. Disability Rights Education & Defense Fund (DREDF): DREDF is a nonprofit organization that supports people with disabilities in the workplace. Their website includes information on employment rights and accommodations, as well as opportunities for training and advocacy.

3. AHEAD: The Association on Higher Education and Disability (AHEAD) is a professional organization that supports disability professionals in higher education. Their website includes information on accommodations for students and employees, as well as resources for training and advocacy.

4. Keep an open dialogue with your employer: Communication is key when it comes to workplace accommodations. Make sure to keep an open and honest dialogue with your employer to ensure that your needs are being met and that any issues or concerns are addressed in a timely manner.

5. Work with a disability professional: If you are struggling to find the right accommodations or are experiencing difficulty at work, consider working with a disability professional or a vocational rehabilitation counselor. They can help you navigate the complex process of requesting accommodations and can provide additional support and resources.

Remember, workplace accommodations are an important part of ensuring that everyone has equal access to employment opportunities. With the right resources and support, you can advocate for your needs and thrive in your career.
